data.title: PRTM Online
data.meta_description: A blog for current and future students of the online Masters degree in Parks, Recreation, Tourism and Sports Management at NC State University
data.text:
Job Posting: Director of Outer Banks Forever

Check out this amazing job opportunity working at the Outer Banks of North Carolina, including such sites as the Cape Hatteras National Seashore, Fort Raleigh National Historic Site, and the Wright Brothers National Memorial!

Eastern National is creating a new branch of their organization to support the philanthropic and programmatic needs of National Park Service partners at the Outer Banks of North Carolina. The Outer Banks Forever branch will allow them to provide centralized support to multiple branches and shared expertise across a range of parks.

The Director will be a key member of Eastern National’s leadership team, and will work closely with various departments within the organization to develop a branch that will support three of the most beloved and visited parks on the Eastern seaboard.

The executive-level Director position will operate with a high level of autonomy to build an entrepreneurial environment and culture within the branch. The Director and their staff will be members of the Eastern National team, with access to back-end administrative support provided by EN’s headquarters in areas like human resources, payroll, benefits, finance, administration, information technology, marketing, and graphic design.

Click here to view the announcement online.

OBX FOREVER Director Position and Details PDF: full position announcement and details for submitting a cover letter and resume.

New Fall DE Elective Option: Woodland Stewardship Online Course

For students looking for online elective options, a new Forestry course will be available for distance education students this Fall semester: Woodland Stewardship, FOR 620-601.

Read more details about the course below and make sure to register ASAP if you are interested!!

This is a great opportunity to get in some agent training, meet a personal goal, or meet the requirement for a 3-credit graduate course required of agents. The course provides an introduction and overview of non-industrial private forestry in the Southeast United States with emphasis on active forest management. Topics include history of human impact on forests, evolution of forest, forestry practices, timber and non timber management objectives, financial aspects of forest land management, and management planning. This course is designed for those who do not have a degree in forestry.

The course is asynchronous and consist of 13 topics in which students will view videos, complete readings, accomplish assignments, and complete assessments on their own over the course of the semester. It also requires participation in an all-day field trip. To move from one topic to the next, students will be required to accomplish all tasks in the current topic prior to being able to move on to the next topic. The course has 10 assignments, 3 quizzes and two exams. Time commitment to the course has similar expectations as that of a 3 credit lecture course.

The 2018 Outstanding Master of PRTSM Student is Matthew Carusona

Please join me in congratulating Matthew Carusona for being awarded as the 2018 Outstanding Master of PRTSM Student!! It should come as no surprise to Matthew’s classmates and professors that he was chosen for this award. Matthew was celebrated last week, along with other award winners and scholarship recipients at the PRTM Alumni and Friend’s Spring Celebration at The StateView Hotel on Centennial Campus.

This year’s decision was a tough choice for our faculty, since there were so many strong students in the graduating cohort. Everyone should be proud of the effort and time they have put in and we are all very proud to have each of you as part of the PRTSM Online Degree.

Congratulations to Jennifer Beaman, Your New GSA Online Student Rep

Congratulations to Jennifer Beaman, who was voted to be the new 2018-2019 PRTSM GSA Online Student Representative. Jennifer will be beginning her 2nd year of the program this summer. Jennifer is currently working as a Medical Assistant and Procedure Coordinator for WakeMed Heart and Vascular. Thank you Jennifer for your willingness to serve and we look forward to you representing the program!

And a big thank you to our first GSA representative, Matthew Carusona, for taking on a new role and doing a wonderful job representing us and communicating with GSA and PRTSM students. Matthew will be graduating in May and we wish him all the best. Thank you Matthew for your service over the last semester!

Position: Club Director for The Ralph E. Capps Teen Center Boys and Girls Club

The Ralph E. Capps Teen Center Boys and Girls Club of Wake Co. is looking for a Club Director. Read about the position below and see the attached document for details and info on how to apply.

The Club Director position requires someone who can:

Provide a quality year around Club program that has

measurable results.

Ensure that members are encouraged to participate in a variety

of program areas/activities and receive instruction and

constructive feedback to develop skills in all program areas. All

members take part in a scheduled orientation about the Club

and the programs offered.

Demonstrate leadership to assure appropriate conduct, safety

and development of members.

Demonstrate leadership in management of facility and grounds.

Building and grounds should represent a quality program and

organization.

Highlights of the position include:

Starting salary is $47,500;

medical/dental/vision insurance 100% paid by employer;

pension;

two paid vacation weeks after 1 year of service.

For more details and how to apply: Club Director – Teen Center – wakebgc.org

Active Living By Design is Hiring!

Active Living By Design seeks qualified candidates to fill two full-time positions: 1) Project Officer or Senior Project Officer and 2) Project Manager. Both positions will work as an integral part of the Active Living By Design team to advance community-led action and place-based strategies to ensure health and well-being for all. Candidates should be flexible with working remotely and, periodically, in office (Chapel Hill).

The Project Officer or Senior Project Officer will engage in project leadership and consultation (technical assistance, coaching, collaborative learning and other services), research and development, business development, and external relations and partnerships. Qualified candidates should have at least 5 years (for Project Officer) or at least 10 years (for Senior Project Officer) of progressive work experience providing consultation and technical assistance to and/or working with diverse healthy communities coalitions. Please visit the posting for a complete listing of the position description, responsibilities and qualifications, and to apply online.

The Project Manager position will contribute to the development and delivery of consultation, technical assistance, collaborative learning, and evaluation services. Related responsibilities include practical research, assessment and evaluation, events planning, writing and communications support. Qualified candidates should have a Bachelor’s Degree, along with at least three to five years of related work and/or volunteer experience. Please visit the posting for a complete listing of the position description, responsibilities and qualifications, and to apply online.

Job Announcement: Assistant Director of Outdoor Pursuits at Wake Forest University

Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, NC is looking for a full-time, 12-month Assistant Director of Outdoor Pursuits.

Summary: The Assistant Director of Outdoor Pursuits increases the participation and diversification of outdoor recreation programs and participants. Coordinates and administers all aspects of Outdoor Pursuits and advises the Wake Adventure Club. Leads the department’s marketing and promotion efforts. Collaborates with Campus Life partners (i.e. Wellbeing, Student Engagement, Global Programs and Studies, Diversity and Inclusion, and the Office of Sustainability) to promote student engagement and foster physical wellbeing by all members of the campus community.

For more information, including essential functions, required skills, and how to apply, click here.

Job Announcement: Boy Scouts of America District Executive Position-Goldsboro NC

Position: District Executive, Boy Scouts of America

Position location: Goldsboro, North Carolina

Council Website: http://www.bsanc.org

In 1923, the Goldsboro Rotary Club and a group of citizens in Smithfield and Kinston started what would eventually become the Tuscarora Council of the Boy Scouts of America. During that time, the organization served 474 boys through 24 troops in Duplin, Greene, Wayne, Johnston and Lenoir counties. The council now serves Duplin, Johnston, Sampson, and Wayne Counties.

The Tuscarora Council proudly serves approximately 7,000 youth and adult volunteers in Duplin, Johnston, Sampson and Wayne Counties of eastern North Carolina.

Please click here for details on the District Executive Position, including position requirements and how to apply.

Graduation Information

BIG CONGRATULATIONS to our PRTSM Online students graduating this May! Please read the following important information regarding all things related to graduation.

1) Apply to Graduate deadline is Friday, 3/16–don’t miss it!

2) The NC State University Commencement Ceremony will take place at PNC Arena on Saturday, May 12th. Details such as start time, arrival information, speaker, etc will all be posted on this page in the next few weeks.

3) The Departmental Commencement Ceremony for the College of Natural Resources will take place on Saturday, May 12th at 3:30 pm at Reynolds Coliseum. You can find all details and parking information here.

I have confirmed with our administration that Masters students WILL walk across the stage at our departmental ceremony at Reynolds Coliseum. You will NOT walk at the main University ceremony at PNC, you just get to stand as your department is announced.

4) Caps, Gowns, and Masters Hood** can all be purchased through the NCSU bookstore online here.

*You must purchase your items by May 2nd in order to have them

shipped to you in time for graduation.

*When ordering a Masters hood, make sure to choose “Natural Resources” from the drop-down menu.

5) All diplomas will be mailed to the address the student listed as their “Diploma or Home/Mailing address” in their MyPack Portal so make sure your personal information is up-to-date. Students who graduate in May will receive their diplomas by the last week in June.

6) Details are subject to change. Be sure to refer to the Student Services Center Graduation website for the most accurate and up-to-date information.

7) If you have any questions or concerns, please let us know sooner rather than later! As the semester moves forward and graduation approaches, things will get hectic for everyone involved so don’t hesitate if you need something.

8) Congratulations!! We are very proud of all of your accomplishments in this program 🙂
